Award.AwardTitle: SusChEM/Collaborative Research: Fundamental Understanding of Foaming Process towards a New Warm Mix Asphalt Technology

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The objective of this award is to understand the foaming process using several foaming agents to guide us in the design of a new warm mix asphalt (WMA) technology. In the proposed project, researchers from Columbia University and Michigan Technological University will investigate three foaming agents as potential candidates, including soda as a chemical foaming agent, CO2/N2 gas and ethanol as physical blowing agents. Multiphase characterization and viscoelastic modeling studies will be conducted to investigate how the microstructure of asphalt materials evolves with time, temperatures, and proportion of material constituents, and in doing so study any differences and relative benefits from chemical vs. physical blowing agents. A single or the combination of foaming agents will be determined for optimal end-results. The fatigue strength, the long-term performance and life cycle cost of the WMA based on the foaming process will be characterized with accelerated test methods.

This project integrates state-of-the-art rheological and accelerated aging tests, thermodynamics, poromechanics, chemical changes and multi-scale modeling to identify the physical and mechanical properties of foamed asphalt materials. The proposed studies will advance the understanding of the foaming process and establish a theoretical framework to predict the material behavior for material design, which will lead to new theories and models of sustainable engineering materials in energy and environmental aspects. This project provides a unique opportunity for conducting interdisciplinary research in sustainable engineering to reduce energy consumption, greenhouse gas emission, to facilitate recycling of asphalt materials, and improve life-cycle performance. The technologies developed in this program will be rapidly transferred to industry.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Project Outcomes Report

Award Title: SusChEM/Collaborative Research: Fundamental Understanding of Foaming Process towards a New Warm Mix Asphalt Technology

Award ID: 1300286

 

We investigated the foaming process using several foaming agents (solid, gas, and liquid). Such process will be able to guide the design of a new warm mix asphalt (WMA) technology. A single or combination of several foaming agents were used in this study. The main conclusions of this project as shown in below:

(1) The possibility of using Ethanol as a foaming agent for low emission asphalt technology was evaluated. Based on the cradle to gate analysis, we found out that smaller energy consumption and Green House Gas (GHG) emission were noted when the ethanol-foamed warm mix asphalt (EWMA) manufactured at a lower temperature.

(2) The temperature reduction of foamed asphalt binder using ethanol was higher than that prepared using water.

(3) Integrated multiphase assessment and rheological characterization were investigated. The preheated binder was formerly foamed using a physical foaming agent (either water or ethanol) and followed by the addition of sodium bicarbonate (NaHCO3) to improve the bubbling and the stability of foam. The result showed that a higher expansion ratio was recorded when the asphalt binder foamed with a higher amount of ethanol. NaHCO3 proportionally increased the volume expansion, while the foaming temperatures did not exhibit a significant impact. The lower production temperature of WMA mixtures improved the long-term performance of asphalt pavement related to fatigue cracking.

(4) The study evaluated the workability, coat-ability and compact-ability of warm mix asphalt mixtures prepared using foamed asphalt binders incorporating ethanol and NaHCO3 as foaming agents. The test results showed that the foamed WMA mixtures prepared at 100°C have comparable or better mixture service characteristics compared to the control HMA prepared at 155°C.

(5) The WMA mixtures prepared using ethanol and ethanol-NaHCO3 foamed binders were tested to evaluate the performance in terms of moisture susceptibility, rutting potential, crack resistance, and thermal cracking potential. The combination of ethanol with 1% NaHCO3 was optimal for these foamed WMA mixtures to maintain the coating characteristics and resistance to moisture damage of the mixtures prepared at 80°C. The resistance to rutting of foamed WMA mixtures increased with the increase in the production temperature. The foamed WMA mixtures exhibited a better resistance to cracking, as indicated by a higher tensile strength as compared to the control HMA.

(6) This study investigated the reliability of dynamic shear rheometer testing (Cup-and-Bob) for evaluating the workability of water-foamed asphalt and analyzed the dynamic foaming process of water-foamed asphalt at different temperatures. The test results indicated that: i) the Cup-and-Bob system was suitable for testing the dynamic properties of water-foamed asphalt; ii) the apparent viscosity of water-foamed asphalt decreased due to the presence of water-bubbles and the fiercely dynamic foaming process, but the rate of decrease of the apparent viscosity of asphalt slowed down as the foaming time and shear rate increased; iii) foamed asphalt’s apparent viscosity and agitation torque was greater than those of asphalt phase in the foamed asphalt at the beginning of the foamed asphalt property testing; v) workability was concluded to be the best when the water content is 3.0%.

(7) Inclusion water left in the asphalt mixture after compaction affects the performance of asphalt mixture. The study investigated the impact of different foaming conditions on the performance of a water-foamed asphalt mixture prepared. Based on the laboratory test results: i) the foaming temperature and the inclusion water from the foaming process significantly affected on the air void and the tensile strength of asphalt mixture, and the void in the mineral aggregate (VMA); ii) the freeze-thaw cycle accelerated the destruction of the internal structure of the asphalt mixture, and resulted in an increase in porosity and decrease in cohesive strength between the asphalt binder and aggregate; iii) the ultrasonic direct test method was found to be a feasible approach to access the potential damage in water-foamed asphalt mixture.

(8) The discrete element method (DEM) based Superpave Gyratory Compactor (SGC) model was applied in the study. The Burgers’ model and the contact bond model were employed to simulate the compaction behavior of asphalt mixture. The influence of the contact model parameters, viscosity parameters, and bond strength upon the compatibility of asphalt mixture were analyzed. The simulation results indicated that: i) DEM-based SGC models displayed a favorable correlation to lab test; ii) the friction coefficient has greater impacts on the void ratio change of the samples than that of the viscosity of the Burger’s model; iii) foamed WMA have better compatibility and smaller void ratios compared with hot mix asphalt (HMA).
